characters: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SOUNDPROOF GLASS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE DRISCOLL sits on the sofa of her psychotherapist's Westwood office. It is a hazy morning. Coastal fog obscur a view to the ocean. Alice looks away to keep from crying.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Brian left me. My wedding is off. Dr. Shemp SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) What was that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You sighed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Did I?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You did, clear as day.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I suppose I'm disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're disappointed. For me or in me?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: For you of course. Alice is silent.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's not unusual for a therapist to develop feelings about a patient especially after seeing them for a number of years, as I have you. Alice wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendly feelings, fatherly feelings -- it's part of the process of transference and counter- transference. Would you like to tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I came home late from work --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice stares into the white vastness of a refrigerator em of everything save a few condiments.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was hungry. As usual, there was nothing in my fridge. She closes the door and walks from her kitchen to her liv room. An easel stands by the window. Canvases, some finished, some not, clutter the room. Alice picks up a se keys from a table by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice leaves her apartment and walks down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I went to Brian's to see if he had anything. She stops just a few doors down and puts her key into the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice enters an apartment different from her own only in decor. She heads straight for the kitchen. Hanging on the refrigerator is a picture of Alice anda handsome man, BRIAN, taken on a ski trip.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He left a letter. Right where he knew I'd find it. Alice opens the door and looks inside. Brian's fridge is barren as her own.  3. A letter hangs from the top shelf with Brian's name signe the bottom. She takes it down and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's session with Dr. Shemp continues.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It said he was going to Alaska. That it was something he'd always dreamed of doing and couldn't put it off any longer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Had he told you about this? Alice shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: (continuing) So that's it? He's gone? Alice shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice stops her brown Volvo in the loading zone. She gets out of the car and runs into the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice scans the "Departures" monitor looking for a flight Alaska. She locates one leaving for Anchorage through gat A26 at 8:30. She looks at the clock. It's 8:25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is at the security checkpoint leading to the gates. GUARD is checking her manually with his metal detector. S looks like she's about to burst The Guard finishes and waves her through. She snares her purse from the conveyor belt and runs towards Gate A26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice arrives at the gate to find Brian's plane in the la stages of loading. She pushes through the crowd, searchin Parents are seeing off children, women give uniformed soldiers parting embraces. She spots a man in newly-purchased adventurewear bending to lift his backpack. BRIAN. He looks up and sees her. He doesn't appear completely surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Did you get the letter?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Alaska? Have you lost your mind? We're getting married in four months. Brian withdraws, looks towards the gate.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe we should put that on hold.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: On hold? Are we breaking up? What's going on? At the gate, a FLIGHT ATTENDANT picks up his microphone.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Last call for flight 018, service to Anchorage.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This is something I need to do. I have to go. Alice and Brian lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's session continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then he left -- Alice shakes her head slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian turns to leave. Alice, without thinking, reaches ou and grabs hold of one of the straps on his backpack and p him towards her with surprising strength.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then it got a little ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits before Dr. Shemp, eyes cast down.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Ugly.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: There was some yelling, I was crying and trying to stop him from leaving -- physically -- it's a little blurry, but I think a security guard was involved. But, yes. He did get on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, her face streaked with tears, her hair and clothes mess, sits slumped in a chair watching as Brian's plane t away from the gate. A Security Guard observes from a safe distance. He looks sorry for her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Had Brian ever exhibited impulsive behavior in the past?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Any history of mental illness?  Alice shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: (continuing) What about his family?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Not that I'm aware of.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: This isn't normal conduct. There must've been warning signs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Brian was everything I ever told you he was -- patient, successful, kind, thoughtful, handsome -- are these the signs of latent psychosis? Silence. Dr. Shemp glances at a clock on the wall behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I'm afraid our time is up. Alice takes her checkbook out of her purse and fills out check. Finished, she hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: (continuing) Perhaps over the coming week you should give some thought as to why you attract this kind of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's car is parked beside a dumpster behind the museum She approaches the service entrance with a heavy bag slun over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The studio is chaotic, packed with little kids playing wi legos, finger paint, cutting shapes out of construction paper. They are loosely supervised by KATHIE and BRANDIE, two interns who are well-kept and ill-meaning.  Alice notices that a four-year-old BOY is systematically emptying cups of glue onto the table top. Kathie and Bran stand GOSSIPING, completely oblivious. Alice hurries up and takes a cup of glue from the kid's h

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (to the interns) Didn't you notice what was happening here? Kathie and Brandie look at the mess on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: Oops. Guess not.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Clean this up, okay? Alice walks off. Kathie whispers to Brandie loud enough f Alice to hear.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: I didn't realize there was a glue shortage. As Alice makes her way across the studio, she is intercep by JUDY, her paranoid middle-aged boss.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: About your request for a door to your office. I'm afraid we're going to have to say no.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Did you look at it? The frame is already in place. All you need is the door.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We don't have any doors.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What if I paid for it myself? It's so noisy in here it's hard to get anything done.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I didn't want to get into this but we have codes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Fire codes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among others, yes. Judy zips off. Alice sighs and heads for her office, a sm cubicle at the corner of the studio.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE OFFICE
dialogues.text: A WEALTHY WOMAN stands over Alice's desk changing her ove child, who, at the moment, is naked and wiggling.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RICH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hunter had an accident. The Wealthy Woman dumps a full and dirty diaper into Alic waste basket.

dialogues.speaker: RICH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't mind, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes, I mind. This is my office.

dialogues.speaker: RICH WOMAN
dialogues.text: How was I supposed to know?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE TURKEY
dialogues.text: (conducting a brief tour) Desk, file cabinet, telephone, office. The Rich Woman stuffs her child into a clean diaper.

dialogues.speaker: RICH WOMAN
dialogues.text: There's no door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What? The Woman picks up her child, preparing to leave.

dialogues.speaker: RICH WOMAN
dialogues.text: Offices have doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is eating ice cream in front of the television. She sets the bowl down on the coffee table.  9. Her cat jumps up and licks up the rest. She reaches out a scratches behind his ears.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice wakes up, having fallen asleep with the television She shuts it off and sits up putting her head in her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice enters Brian's dark and empty apartment

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alice crawls into Brian's bed and buries her face in his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the day. Alice ushers the last few stragglers out the door. She pulls down an aluminum gate locks it. Kathie and Brandie are chatting as they clean up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: -- there I was sitting on a throne on the banks of the Nile.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDIE
dialogues.text: What were you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: A long gold dress with slits up both sides.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDIE
dialogues.text: Like the Donna Karan we saw at the Beverly Center?

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. I had a killer retro tan and bracelets winding up both arms like snakes. Alice walks by.  10.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: BRANDIE
dialogues.text: Kathie saw a past-life medium. Alice pauses to listen.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, there are these soldiers they're wearing these little leather skirts -- Brandie makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) They made it work. So they drag up this slave or husband or something and without thinking I say, "Off with his head!"

dialogues.speaker: BRANDIE
dialogues.text: I have got to try this. Alice moves towards her office, keeping one ear on Kathie

dialogues.speaker: BRANDIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's the woman's name?

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: Varya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is in another session. Dr. Shemp observes. His expression is impenetrable.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's not fair, I miss him, and I don't even get to be mad at him because he's not here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should explore where this anger is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I think it's a natural reaction.  11.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: We're not talking about what's natural, we're talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I thought I was getting married and now I'm not. This hurts me. Because I'm hurt I want to lash out.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Perhaps you're really angry with your father. Alice elects to ignore this interpretation.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I realized last night that the world is primarily unfair. I know it sounds obvious, look at the Holocaust for God's sake. It's not a logical thought, more the sudden realization that I've lived my life believing that things come around, that good things happen to good people, that life affords us compensation equal to our suffering. But it's all delusional bullshit, isn't it? Do you believe in past lives?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: What do you mean? In the sense of a Jungian collective consciousness?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, in the I was the third wife of Henry the Eighth sense.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I'm more from the object relations school -- Winnicott, Fairbairn, good breast, bad breast --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: There's a good breast and a bad breast?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: According to Melanie Klein, yes. Alice looks at her own breasts in turn.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is watching television in sweats. Mr. Fabulous is o her chest, PURRING. A half-empty bowl of popcorn sits on coffee table next to a half-empty bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE T.V.
dialogues.text: They're showing the "Wizard of Oz."

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (to Toto) There's no place like home. Alice reaches for the remote and shuts off the set.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE TURKEY
dialogues.text: (to Dorothy) Speak for yourself. Alice carries the popcorn bowl to the kitchen. The place amess. She dumps the bowl in the sink. She spots the Yellow Pages, thinks, and pulls it from the shelf. She plops herself down at the table and looks up a listin She finds it under "V" in a very small box. The ad reads: Varya Past Life Medium "Escape to Yourself" Alice reads off the number and reaches for the phone. She stops herself just as she's about to dial.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE TURKEY
dialogues.text: (to herself) Come on, Alice, get a grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice lies in bed, tossing and turning, unable to sleep. Glancing at her alarm clock, she sees that it's two in th morning.  13. She rises from bed, taking her clock with her. She gather up Mr. Fabulous and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice lies sleeping in Brian's bed with Mr. Fabulous curl up on top of her. Hearing FOOTSTEPS approaching, Mr Fabulous wakes and looks around. A key SCRATCHES in the doorway. Alice half wakes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Brian? Alice sits up, comes to her senses. It can't be Brian. Sh hears the sound of someone entering the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh my God. Alice gets herself out of bed and to the door. She opens a tiny crack and looks through.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: What appears to be an INTRUDER enters the apartment. He's wearing coveralls and is carrying a cardboard box. Someth in a soft case is hanging from his back. His hair is shag and unkempt but it's too dark to make out his face.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alice backs away from the door, terrified. She picks up t phone beside the bed but there is no dial tone, it's been disconnected. There is a lot of THUMPING around outside. Alice is begin to panic. She hears FOOTSTEPS coming towards her. Alice slips into the closet and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice can hear that the intruder has entered the room. Sh gropes around for something to defend herself with and fi an old fraternity paddle. The intruder tries to pull open the closet door. Alice sl it shut from inside. There is a pause.  14.

dialogues.speaker: INTRUDER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Alice says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INTRUDER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Is this Brian Doon's apartment?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's Doan. Brian Doan. who are you?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'm Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kevin who?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Just Kevin, I'm his sublet Alice peeks out the door. KEVIN stands before her, holdin Mr. Fabulous who seems quite comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you live here?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No. I -- She puts down the paddle.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I guess I don't need this.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Is this your cat? Alice nods.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nice cat. Are you a homeless person? I could come back.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, I live here, in the building, I'm sorry -- She takes Mr. Fabulous from him.  15.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll get out of your way. And she is gone. Kevin goes to his box and opens it. It is full of groceri He finds a banana, peels and eats it. He takes a carton o milk and carries it to the fridge. He looks at the pictur of Alice and Brian on the door.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Banana in hand, Kevin wanders into Brian's bedroom and fl on the light. The imprint of Alice's body is still clearly visible on t right side of the unmade bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday morning. Alice stands before a blank canvas waitin for inspiration. She dips her brush into a blob of yellow ochre but is wra with indecision and cannot apply it. She puts down her brush and soaks a wad of newspaper with paint thinner. The solvent highlights a classified ad for Varya, the pas life medium. The ad is identical to the one she saw in th Yellow Pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Referring to an address written on a scrap of paper, Alic walks up to the door of a normal-looking house somewhere Los Feliz. She reaches out and knocks hesitantly. A VOICE (with a faint Eastern European accent), calls out from inside.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes? Who is it?  16.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's Alice Driscoll, I had an appointment for noon. The door BUZZES. Alice pushes it open and walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind chimes move gently in the breeze from the skylight above. The walls are covered with abstract paintings. Ali pauses to look at one of them. VARYA enters from the living room, drying her hands on a dishcloth. She is a handsome woman in her early forties a is dressed casually.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Hello, I am Varya. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. (of the painting) Did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: (of the painting) It is my brother's. I am not an artist, I have little interest in suffering. But you, I see, area painter.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How did you know? Varya points to Alice's hands which are lightly stained w paint.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: You're a little early, come -- Varya leads her down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya and Alice are sitting at the kitchen table eating grilled cheese.  17.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: It would be better if there were tomato soup.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: This is great, I wasn't expecting lunch. Varya takes the last bite of her sandwich and wipes her h on a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: So. Tell me why you are here.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Someone at work was talking about you. I saw your ad. I usually don't go for this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: But you are in a time of stress.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: And you were curious.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I am curious.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Our eyes illuminate only a dim path before us and our memory distorts what we leave behind. A dark curtain obscures everything else. I imagine that there are people in the world who never wonder what is behind the curtain. I find this very strange. Varya takes their plates to the sink and rinses them unde the tap.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have you ever had the feeling you have lived other lives?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I've always hoped there was something more than this.  18. varya fills a silver bowl with about an inch of water.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: You were raised a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Catholic, yes.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: But you no longer practice. Varya returns to her seat and places the silver bowl betw them.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I haven't been in a church since I was ten. Alice watches as Varya wets her index finger in the bowl. holds it above the surface of the water.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Leaving an emptiness you try to fill with your art. Innocent blood, the beauty of martyrdom --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: -- peace on earth and sexless unions. Alice watches a drop of water fall from Varya's finger in the bowl. The waves ripple and return in slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Do you feel comfortable leaving here now?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Shall we go back? Alice is transfixed by the water.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We shall.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: If you find yourself somewhere you don't like, simply say the word "help" and we will go to another place. Do you understand?  19. Alice nods. She watches as another drop falls from Varya' finger. Alice hears the sound of HOWLING WIND. The water in the b darkens, eddies, and closes in, filling her entire frame vision. Alice retreats into her trance.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tell me where we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water runs between the banks of the river Neva in St. Petersburg. An ebony troika is pulled briskly along the riverbank by two spirited white stallions. Sitting in the troika is a BEAUTIFUL WOMAN, wrapped in gr sable, a member of the Russian aristocracy circa 1850.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think it's Russia, yes, in the time of the Czars. The woman and her troika and her magnificent horses gallo past, revealing an awful sight. TWENTY PEASANTS are bound by long ropes to a barge of coa and are being used as human oxen to pull it up river. At the head of the line are two massive, toothless PEASAN WOMEN whose backs have nearly been broken by hard labor. The second one in line speaks to the first.

dialogues.speaker: BABUSHKA 2, (RUSSIAN SUBTITLES)
dialogues.text: Pull harder, Alice, the day is short and our husbands are drunkards. The first peasant stops in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: BABUSHKA 1, (RUSSIAN SUBTITLES)
dialogues.text: Did you say my name was Alice?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help.  20.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SKY
dialogues.text: Dark, heavy clouds give way to a deep blue sky and rollin green hills.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are we now? A lovely white house is nestled in a wooded bower. A new model T Ford is parked in the garage. A very handsome MAN wearing work clothes circa 1920 searches the yard. He loo distressed.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME MAN
dialogues.text: Alice! Alice! Where did you go? (looks around) Alice!! The Handsome Man goes inside the barn for a look

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE BARN
dialogues.text: The Handsome Man can be heard calling out from inside.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Alice! Chickens, geese, and ducks scatter at the sound of his vo The handsome Man comes out the rear door of the barn, see only from the waist down. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME MAN
dialogues.text: There you are. A large TURKEY stands frozen in fear, staring at the Hand Man, who is revealed to be holding a well-sharpened ax.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME MAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Happy Thanksgiving, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE TURKEY
dialogues.text: Help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya is at the stove pouring two cups of tea. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: This is very unusual.  21. Varya sets the tea down at the table and resumes her seat

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don't know why I thought my past lives would be any better than this one.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Could we try once more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 1960 Ford pickup ambles down a dusty road in the Deep South. It passes by a roadside diner called JUMBO'S and keeps going. A woman sits on the front step, smoking a cigarette. She wears checked pants, a cook's shirt, and has a short apro tied around her waist. Her hair is falling out of the bobby pins that have been haphazardly stabbed here and there. ANNE CARVER is the spitting image of the Alice of today.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It looks like I'm a cook ina diner. Somewhere in the Deep South.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you like to go somewhere else? She looks up. Three long black Cadillacs are coming towar her at a pretty good clip.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait. Approaching the diner, the Cadillacs slow and turn into t parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let's see what happens. Anne crushes her cigarette under her heel and heads back the diner.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, clean place with six tables and six booths. It i mid-afternoon and completely empty. A waitress named DORI sits in the corner booth over a magazine and a cup of cof She hears the JINGLE of a bell over the door and looks towards it. Four men swagger in. Their hair is lifted and slicked bac they wear black jumpsuits with the collars turned up and their pant legs are tucked into their boots. Wrap-around sunglasses shield their eyes. They are known as the MEMPH MAFIA. Two more MEN follow closely behind. The first has a fat, jowly face and a cigar crammed into corner of his mouth. This is COLONEL TOM PARKER. He uses cane purely as affectation. The second is a modest Young Man in a tweed sport coat an black tie. Doris's jaw drops as she recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Is it -- are you -- him?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, I'm Elvis Presley. Elvis sits with the others. Doris approaches and takes ou her pen and order pad but her hands are shaking and the p falls to the floor near Elvis's feet. Elvis picks it up and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think you'll be needing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris approaches the line, behind which Anne and Junior nervously await. She tears a chit from her order pad and puts it beneath t spring on the order wheel, then she does it a second time and a third, and a fourth, and to Anne's astonishment a f before spinning the wheel towards them.  23.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Order in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and Junior move through the kitchen preparing the Ki order. Doris sits off to the side on a milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Who'd have thought a man could be that pretty and still be such a man? She looks into a small pocket mirror and applies red lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) My heart skid to a stop when he smiled at me. Junior looks at the order. He reaches into a drawer, coun off three hamburger patties, and slaps them on the grill where bacon sizzles near a neatly cornered pile of hash browns. Anne slides open a refrigerated drawer beneath the cuttin board and removes a covered pan. Turning back to the stov she fires the burner under a second skillet and pours in oil.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Which order is his?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The five bacon and mustard sandwich. Junior flips four slices of white bread into a four slice toaster. Moving down the line, he stirs up a bowl of hush puppy batter and dollops silver dollar sized portions int the heated skillet.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do you think he'd take offense if I asked for his autograph?

dialogues.speaker: JUMBO
dialogues.text: Definitely not. Elvis isa generous man.  24. Anne shakes a layer of cornmeal directly onto the cutting board and smooths it evenly with the palm of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What do you know about Elvis? She reaches into the pan and fishes out two catfish fille which have been marinating in mustard, cream, and various spices. She holds the fillets above the pan, allowing the marinade to run off.

dialogues.speaker: JUMBO
dialogues.text: I pick up a newspaper now and again. (to Doris) Get one for me too, would ya?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He ain't gonna be in sucha generous mood if you burn those hush puppies. JUMBO shakes the pan and starts turning them with a fork.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) What are you going to have him sign? Anne rolls the catfish fillets in the cornmeal and lowers them carefully into the skillet

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't know, I hadn't given it any thought.

dialogues.speaker: THE DINER
dialogues.text: The Memphis Mafia is horsing around; doing the spot trick balancing unscrewing the caps to the salt and pepper shak trying to keep Elvis entertained. Doris approaches, balancing all six of their plates. She sets down Elvis's first, then Colonel Parker's, then the others. JOE, the mafia's ring leader, takes Doris aside and whisp something naughty in her ear.  25.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Anne peeks out from behind the line. Elvis catches her looking at him. She quickly turns away, pretending to be busy.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Elvis looks over his sandwich. He removes the top slice o toasted bread and reaches for the salt shaker.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Anne is watching again. She cringes. Elvis is about to dump the salt when he changes his mind sets the shaker down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (to herself) Good boy.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Elvis reassembles his sandwich. He raises it to his mouth and takes a bite. Chewing slowly, he finds himself transported into a state of complete bliss. The Colonel notices and looks at him funny.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: What is it, boy? You all right?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: This is the best damn sandwich I ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Memphis Mafia leaves the restaurant. Elvis is already gone. Colonel Parker waits behind in the booth, chomping his cigar. Anne approaches from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You asked to see me? Parker offers the seat across from him. Anne takes it.  26.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Elvis has been looking for someone who can come to Los Angeles and cook so as he doesn't get homesick while he's working there. Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Kids? Anne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Bad habits?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I like to sleep in on Sundays.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Are you a fan?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: A fan, an Elvis Presley fan?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I've heard Mr. Presley on the radio, but I must confess, his music does not move me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior is ringing out the register. Anne sits on a booth before it. Outside, one of the Cadillacs pulls away. The other one stays behind.

dialogues.speaker: JUMBO
dialogues.text: I'd be hard pressed to name one good reason for you to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: There's you. Doris hops out of the back seat of the second limo and ru to the door as it pulls away.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JUMBO
dialogues.text: You think I'll starve to death? Go Doris bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Did he do it? Doris takes her underpants from her pocket and holds them out. "Elvis Presley" has been signed across the butt in b broad strokes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He made you take them off?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That was my idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice has awoken from her trance in a big way. She sits across from Varya with her eyes open wide.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You have to send me back!

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid your time is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is in her session. Dr. Shemp looks uncharacteristically nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: You don't really think you were a short order cook in a past life, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It was fun, it seemed real enough at the time.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Freud said, "To live without a dream is impossible, but to live within a dream is insanity."

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You think I should stop seeing her.  28.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I don't tell you what you can and cannot do, that would be directive.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE TURKEY
dialogues.text: (to herself) Why Elvis? I've never really been that much of a fan.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: It's natural to go through a state of denial. You've lost your fiancee. On the list of major stressors, it ranks closely with the death of a loved one.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Which is sandwiched right between moving and losing your pet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: There are healthier ways to deal with stress. You could go for a walk, or try diaphragmatic breathing. Alice looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're right, I'm acting like an insane person. I'll call and cancel as soon as I get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin sits in the window box with his guitar on his lap a piece of peanut butter toast in his mouth. He strums a fe awkward chords and hums something before chewing his bite puts down the toast and looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Alice leaves the building, holding a small paper sack. Ke watches her unchain her bike and pedal off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya opens the door to find Alice standing there, holdin her paper sack.  29.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I brought this. She fishes out a can of Campbell's Tomato Soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying her suitcase in her hand, Anne steps from the walkway into the main terminal of LAX, and into the large group of people she's ever seen gathered in one place. She sets down her suitcase and opens her purse. She searc anxiously until she finds a well-thumbed piece of paper w instructions written on it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne steps into a taxi cab and hands the piece of paper t the DRIVER. He glances at it briefly and pulls away from curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A throng of GROUPIES have gathered at the scrolled iron g outside Elvis's home away from home, hoping to catch a glimpse of the King. Anne's taxi pulls into the drive. A SECURITY GUARD takes a look at her identification, chec her name off a list, and shows her through. The Groupies look on enviously as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE'S TAXI
dialogues.text: Anne rolls down her window as Elvis's mansion comes into view. The lawns are perfectly manicured, the bricks are washed white, a tacky fountain sprays water into the air. BEEP! BEEP! A souped-up golf cart driven by a Memphis Maf member shoots across the drive, forcing the CAB DRIVER to make an abrupt stop. Three other carts follow right behind, one of them is dri by Elvis, though they're moving so fast it's hard to tell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls away and Anne carries her small suitcase t the front door. She sets it down and rings the bell.  30. MAGGIE, a middle-aged housekeeper, answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Hello, my name's Anne. I'm the new cook.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maggie. Thank God you're here. Maggie relieves Anne of her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let me show you your room.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MANSION
dialogues.text: As Maggie leads the way up a curving staircase, Anne can' help but gape at the crystal chandelier, the opulent paintings and statuary, the marble floor, and the impossi high ceilings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is alone in a pretty little room which has a view on the drive. Her suitcase is open and she is unpacking. Hearing the ROAR of engines, she goes to the window and l out.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DRIVE
dialogues.text: Elvis and the Mafia are firing up their motorcycles. Elvi has a Harley Davidson, the others ride Triumphs. Anne watches as they pull out in wing formation with Elvi leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Something startles Anne as she turns back to her suitcase Colonel Parker is standing in the doorway, watching her

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to frighten you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: With all the noise, I didn't hear you coming, Colonel Parker.  31.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: No need to be so formal. You can call me Colonel Tom. Do you have everything you need?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: A few rules before you start. You're here to cook, that's all. Elvis is a busy man, he doesn't need any friends and he don't need any advice. Any private life happens outside those gates. You're here because Elvis wants you here, but you are employed by me. If there are any problems you come to me first and last, understood?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Colonel Parker turns to leave and pauses at the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Supper's at six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is hard at work in Elvis's modern (c. 1965) kitchen. slips into hot pads, opens the oven door, and slides out perfect sweet potato pies. She sniffs them as she sets them out to cool. Removing her oven mitts, she reaches for a pastry brush a stainless steel bowl.

dialogues.speaker: PATIO
dialogues.text: Racks and racks of ribs cook slowly over white hot coals. Anne gives them each a generous coat of BBQ sauce.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Anne takes a damp towel from four loaves of freshly-risen bread. She adjusts the oven temperature and slides them inside. She fills a glass of water at the tap and tosses it into bottom of the oven, filling it with steam to brown the cr  32. Moving to the fridge, she opens it and takes out four egg She cracks them into a copper bowl and whisks them until they're frothy. On a covered platter are sectioned pieces of frying chick She dips the chicken into the beaten egg and dredges them spiced flour. She does this with four other pieces and lays them into a shallow pan of hot oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis, Col. Parker, and the Memphis Mafia are seated arou the table. what is left of Anne's magnificent meal is spr out before them.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: So I find this one girl, she's willing, she's pretty, but she's too damn tall. So she introduces me to her friend, just as good- looking, maybe even better, but she couldn't have even made five feet I tell them this isn't going to work out, that Elvis likes a girl of average height. And the tall one says, how about we both go, it'll even out. LAUGHTER from the Mafia. Colonel Tom smirks and lights a cigar. Elvis doesn't even notice. He reaches for another piece o chicken and takes a bite. He shakes his head, unable to believe how good it is. Maggie enters to clear the table. She reaches for Elvis's plate and he stops her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'm just beginning to hit my stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is putting whipped cream on the sweet potato pie. A tray of homemade peanut butter cookies is beside it, alon with an icebox cake.  33. Maggie enters carrying an armful of dirty plates. She unloads them at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I've always known those boys were pigs, but I've never seen them eat like this before. Anne is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Elvis would like you to come out and say hello when you've got a minute. Anne freezes. She ditches her apron and starts working on her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone sits around the table, smoking, drinking, and yukking it up. Elvis is dipping cookies in milk. Anne enters through the swinging doors. Jimmy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How'd you get in here? Anne points to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Through there, through the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Relax, boy, she's the new cook.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I thought you were a fan.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, sir, I am a paid employee.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You don't look like no cook.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And what is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Cooks are big, fat, old and greasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because I cook like your momma, doesn't mean I gotta look like her. You could hear a pin drop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (to herself) I can't believe I said that. Low LAUGHTER is heard. It's coming from Elvis. The others join in as if on cue. only one who remains unamused is Colonel Parker.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I think Joe was trying to give you a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Growing up in a diner gives you a sharp tongue.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (to Joe) She's right, though, your mother is an ugly woman.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Watch it, Red. I won't take that from you.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (to Anne) Anyone who makes food this good is entitled to say what they want. What's your name, darlin'?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Anne. Elvis offers his hand and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Anne, I'm Elvis Presley.  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits poolside on a chaise lounge. He is wearing sunglasses and swim trunks and is reading a screenplay. A small electric fan is pointed right at him. Anne exits the house carrying a tray with a Pepsi, a pitc of crushed ice, and some Pepto Bismol. She crosses the ya and sets the tray down on a glass-topped table beside him

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, darlin'.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (of the Pepto) You're not feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I always get a little sick to my stomach when I'm learning my lines.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Is it nerves?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No, it's the lines. He puts the script aside.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have you heard of a band called the Beatles? Anne nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) They're coming by this afternoon, I don't know if they're gonna be hungry or not.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'll have something ready.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: The food's not too good in England, so be careful. You don't want to give ~em culture shock or anything.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'll be careful.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I ever met a woman more difficult to impress. You're not an Elvis Presley fan, I tell you the Beatles are stopping by and you look like it's just another day. What does a man have to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: There's no need to impress me. Anne turns to leave and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) But do warn me if Sinatra ever plans to stop by. I might want to change my dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne lies on her bed, leafing through a magazine. She hea a car pull into the drive. She goes to the window and peeks through the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DRIVE
dialogues.text: The FAB FOUR climb out of a black limousine. They take in their surroundings greedily, as excited as little kids. Elvis greets them and shows them inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne walks down the corridor into the bathroom. She is surprised to find Maggie there, sitting on the floor. Maggie puts her finger to her lips and motions Anne towar her. Anne complies, kneeling beside her. Maggie directs her ea to a vent, through which they can hear VOICES coming from room below. Elvis and the Beatles are jamming, they sing "LAWDY MISS

dialogues.speaker: CLAWDY."
dialogues.text: Anne and Maggie listen with their ears glued to the vent.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is sitting at the kitchen table, working on a menu p Maggie is at the sink, doing the dishes from breakfast. Elvis enters looking ragged in a white terry cloth robe. gets up immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Morning. Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No thanks. He opens the fridge, takes out a bottle of whole milk, an drinks down about half of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Could you bring lunch by the set today?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Of course. Anything in particular?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What was it I had at the diner that first time?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: The five bacon and mustard sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, bring me four or five of those. He reads her surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) The input's gotta match the output.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits on the front step of the mansion next to a wick basket covered with a red checked cloth. Red pulls up in his Cadillac. He hops out and opens the b door for her. She sets the basket on the seat.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Could I sit in front? TI get carsick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red drives down Melrose Avenue on his way to Paramount Studios. Anne sits beside him, taking in the sights. Red fishes a package of Tareyton's out of his shirt pocke

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: You mind?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Not unless you mind sharing. Red shakes out two cigarettes and gives one to Anne. He flips open a Zippo and lights it for her.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Ever been on a movie set before?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No. It must be exciting.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Sorry to burst your bubble. E says if you have any taste for movies or sausage you shouldn't watch either being made.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: That's clever.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: See? It's so damn boring it's turning Elvis into a philosopher Anne spots a sign.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Vine Street! Where's Hollywood Boulevard? Red points to the left.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Up that way five streets or so. I'll take you by on the way back if you'd like.  39.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: That would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Elvis really likes you. You probably know that all ready.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Elvis likes my cooking.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: He didn't send me to just pick up the food. Anne takes a drag off her cigarette. He LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (continuing) Elvis has always had the highest regard for people who take pride in what they do.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What is it you do exactly?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I'm a catch-fart. Elvis farts, I catch it. No, I watch after the money.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Isn't that the Colonel's job?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: The Colonel's got his own money to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red's Cadillac takes a left turn into Paramount Studios. signals to the Security Guard who waves him through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red and Anne stand outside a soundstage on the Paramount waiting for the red light to go off. Anne watches EXTRAS parade past in costume, STAGE HANDS m large backdrops, long cars pass by with tinted windows.  40. The light goes off and Red leads Anne inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits in a director's chair watching a take.

dialogues.speaker: ON SET
dialogues.text: Elvis stands amongst potted palm trees against a painted backdrop of the view from a South Sea Island. He is wearing a sailor's suit and hat and is strumming a stringless guitar to PLAYBACK. Buxom STARLETS dancing in bikinis surround him. The song comes to an end. The DIRECTOR steps out from the wings.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Cut! That was great, Elvis, let's break for lunch. From the look on Elvis's face, he doesn't seem to think i was so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits at the small table in his trailer eating his f bacon and mustard sandwich. Anne sits nearby, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Would you rather be alone?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You'd better stay in here where it's safe. This town's crawling with wolves.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So what does that make you?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Me? I'm just a nice boy from Tupelo, Mississippi. (takes a bite) Least that's what it says in the papers.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What's this movie about?  41.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I play a kid from the wrong side of the tracks who sings his way into everyone's hearts. Same story, different location.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don't you like movies?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I love movies, just not mine. Someday I'd like to see Elvis doa picture with no songs.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No one thinks he can act.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You're the one that matters. You are him, after all.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No, Elvis is a nice boy from Tupelo, Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Who sings his way into people's hearts. A Production Assistant KNOCKS on Elvis's trailer.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They want you on set, Mr. Presley.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Thanks for lunch. Elvis takes a last bite of his sandwich and rises to his He stops at the door and takes a deep breath, trying to summon some enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) T.C.B., takin' care of business.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is asleep in her room at the Bel Air mansion. Faint MUSIC and LAUGHTER can be heard coming from far off. The telephone beside her bed RINGS, startling her awake.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? Wait, I'll get a pen. She finds a pen and a pad of paper in the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay, go ahead. Ten cheeseburgers six chocolate milk shakes, one strawberry, okay -- (listens) What's a butter sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne wheels a room service push-cart up to Elvis's door. answers. He is sweaty, drunk, and his shirt is open to th waist.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Anne, you're a peach. You can leave that right here. Through a crack in the door, Anne catches a glimpse of El standing on the bed. He's wearing a gi tied together with a black belt and is working through a theatrical karate routine. Four adoring YOUNG WOMEN sit at his feet, drinking champagne from a bottle. Joe wheels the cart inside and closes the door

dialogues.speaker: VARYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Alice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits with her eyes open, staring into space. Varya SNAPS her fingers in front of her.  43.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Alice, wake up! Alice comes out of it, albeit reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your time is up.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh. Already. She goes to her purse.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Strangest sensation. It's like knowing yourself as a child.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Would you like another appointment?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you have anything tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice lies on the sofa eating potato chips watching "Wild the Country."

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: Elvis is driving a truck, fiddling with the radio. The lovely Tuesday Weld sits beside him. Miss Weld is frustra by this action, she wants to talk. Elvis continues to play with the radio. Arriving at a son he likes he turns up the volume.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (to Miss Weld) You're going to hear music whether you like it or not -- And he breaks into song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is still watching "Wild in the Country." Mr. Fabulo hops up onto her chest for some attention, which he gets.  44.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: Elvis and his therapist, played by the talented and somew older Hope Lange, are caught in a torrential downpour. They take shelter in a hotel. Elvis tries for intimacy. H Lange holds him off. She returns to her room, Elvis follows.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (to Hope Lange) I'm in love with you. They embrace with something more like tenderness than passion. The scene is really something. A telephone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: It's Alice's phone. She sits up and hits "pause." She stares for a while at the image on her television and let the machine answer for her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (on machine) Alice? It's your mother. Pick up the phone, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE'S MOTHER pushes a cart through the meat section of upscale market. Alice tags along reluctantly in sweats an sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Because I know you won't eat if I don't. Alice's mother takes something heavy from the case and dr it into the cart. Alice fishes it out and holds it up. It is a four-pound roast.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: It's a veal roast.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I'll never eat it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: What you don't eat you can use for sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don't eat veal, it's disgusting. They live their whole lives in these little pens unable to move being force fed hormone-laced protein.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: A short unhappy life is better than no life at all. Alice gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (sighs) All right, put it back. Alice does. Her mother immediately replaces the roast wit five-pound package of hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice and her Mother are third in a line of four at the checkout counter.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Have you made up with Brian yet?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: "Made up"? Mom, we can't make up, Brian is in Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: They don't have phones in Alaska?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He's gone. He didn't leave a number. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh, baloney sausage.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He sublet his apartment.  46.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: If you only knew the half of what your father and I went through you'd think this was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Here we go. Alice's Mother takes a deep breath and Alice clamps her h over her ears. ALICE’S MOTHER ALICE After his vasectomy, your Dad I'm not listening -- blah went completely berserk. He blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, bought a yellow sports car blah, blah, blah, I can't and the whole catalogue of hear you -- blah, blah, blah, Herb Alpert and the Tijuana blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, Brass. It seemed to be the blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, soundtrack of the mid-life blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, crisis. Then he started blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, chasing Mrs. Polynsky around -_ blah, BLAH! Alice's Mother gives up.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I just don't want you to have unrealistic expectations of what marriage is like.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: There are no expectations, there are no children, there is no marriage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's Mother is inside her car. Alice stands beside it, with two bags of groceries at her feet

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: You know all I want is for you to be happy.  47.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I know. Alice leans in and gives her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetheart. Alice's Mother looks to the building.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Watch out for the bum on your way in. Alice turns. Kevin sits on the sidewalk beside the front door and is sound asleep. Alice's Mother drives off. Alice picks up her groceries a goes to Kevin. She shakes him lightly, trying to rouse hi It doesn't work. She pushes harder and he finally stirs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kevin? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I locked myself out.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I see that. Come on, I'll let you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice unlocks Brian's door and opens it for Kevin. He ste inside.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I have coffee. Alice doesn't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I could make you some.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits alone in Brian's living room. Kevin enters carrying two, too-full cups of coffee. He sloshes some on the floor as he crosses the room. He hands a cup to Alice. She gives a nod of thanks. Kevin sits opposite. He watches her sip her coffee like a littl bird. There is a long silence. Very long.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'm not usually this gregarious.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'm on a new medication. The first two weeks are the honeymoon period. Alice smiles and looks at him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I'm a program director at the children's museum.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I don't know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I'm an art waitress. If a parent decides their kid needs culture, they bring them in and I serve it up. Alice looks around, taking stock of familiar objects. She notices Kevin watching her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) How much do you know about me and Brian?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Pretty much everything. I've read your letters.  49. Alice looks startled.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I made some changes. I think they're pretty good now. I come up more often than I used to. Realizing he's kidding, Alice opens her hand and looks at keys. She begins to remove Brian's from her ring.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I meant to give this to you before.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Could you keep it? Then I'll know for sure where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is in her session. Her hair is back and she is wear a pretty dress and shoes with heels.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: So instead of "Perfect Brian" living down the hall, you now have "Defective Kevin." He's unemployed, delusional, and vaguely suicidal.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: He's in the right apartment. I might as well date him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: You're not seriously thinking of having a relationship with him?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Of course not. He's the last thing I need right now.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: That was a joke then.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Dr. Shemp forces a brief, weird smile.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I'd like to tell you that you look pretty today.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: You look very nice today.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Is this the psychologically healthy way to dress? Flowers signifying helplessness, fragile, easily-torn fabrics, awkward shoes to hinder any attempt at escape? The male ideal. I shouldn't be surprised you noticed. Dead silence.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: If you ever decide you need more than one session a week, I could make time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already half in a trance, Alice watches drops of water fa from Varya's finger into the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: You're thinking of nothing, you're letting everything go. we're taking you back --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (as Anne) Ten pounds of pig's feet, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne stands at the meat counter with a long list. The car beside her is almost full of wrapped items. A HELPFUL BUTCHER attends.

dialogues.speaker: HELPFUL BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Pig's feet, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: That's right.  51.

dialogues.speaker: HELPFUL BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Did you know you were in a kosher market?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (covering) Of course, I --

dialogues.speaker: HELPFUL BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You might want to try Hansen's on Third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne stands outside a small meat market on Third Street w her order wrapped in white paper. Another Helpful Butcher giving her directions. Red gets out of his Cadillac to lend a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red waits nervously in his car in a predominantly African American neighborhood. PASSERSBY eye him up like he's jus arrived from another planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLERK is rummaging through cartons of produce, helping select various greens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne stands at the stove, over a pot of boiling water. Be the pot is a large frying pan filled with halved onions sauteing in butter. Each one is turned carefully, revealing the golden brown underside. She extinguishes the heat from beneath the oni and uncovers two pie tins with the crust already pressed the bottom of the pan. She arranges the onions neatly ins the pie crust. Turning back to the stove, she pours two inches of cookin oil into another pan and lights a high flame beneath it. She slides the top crust to the onion pie from between tw floured sheets of waxed paper. She places it carefully on top and crimps it around the edges.  52. With a sharp boning knife she scores a rose pattern into crust. She opens the oven and slides the pie inside. She turns her attention to a cutting board where a heapin pile of cut and cleaned okra awaits. She covers the okra with salt and pepper. She snaps open a clean paper bag an pours in a cup and a half of corn meal. She slides the okra into the bag, shakes it quickly and p it into the pan with the hot oil. From the refrigerator comes a bucket of washed and cleane collard greens. Anne scoops them out with both hands and dumps them in the pot of boiling water. She selects an apple from a basket on the counter, rinses under the sink, and starts peeling it with a paring knife Maggie enters. She goes to the sink to wash her hands. Sh looks to Anne and notices that she has begun to have trou with the apple. The knife slips and she nearly cuts herself. Trying again she is put off when a tremor, beginning at her shoulder, extends down the length of her left arm, forcing her to p down her work.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You feel all right, dear?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Fine, I don't know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you need a doctor? The tremor has subsided.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: There, it's gone. It's nothing. Anne gets back to paring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits at the end of his long table. The Memphis Mafi are in their usual places doing their usual things. Every has finished eating but Elvis. He slides the serving dish of collard greens towards him loads up his plate. He salts the greens heavily and scoop some into his mouth.  53. While chewing he grabs another hunk of corn bread and som butter. He looks to a gravy-strewn serving platter and to his disappointment finds it empty. Elvis notices that Red has an untouched pig's foot left o his plate.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (to Red) You gonna eat that? Red shakes his head. Elvis skewers the pig's foot. The Colonel enters carrying a briefcase. He walks up to Elvis, looking mighty pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: We need to talk a little business.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (mouth full) I'll be there in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Parker sits out on the patio behind the kitchen smoking his cigar. He watches through the window as Anne serves up apple pie with scoops of vanilla ice cream. Maggie carries the plates into the dining room. Anne goes the back door and sticks her head out.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Would you care for pie, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'll pass.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: If you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel swallows the dregs of his coffee. He sighs an looks at his watch.  54.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Anne is working on cleaning up the mess from dinner. Elvi enters with a toothpick in his mouth. He is all smiles an compliments. Anne thanks him modestly and Elvis heads outside.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PATIO
dialogues.text: Elvis plops himself down next to the Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: So I'm in my office today, minding my own business, and guess who walks in? Elvis shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Abe Lastfogel, along with all three of the Mirisch brothers.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Don't know ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: They produced "West Side Story," "The Magnificent Seven" --

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Those are good pictures.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: They got a fat distribution deal with United Artists. They tell me they're interested in doing an Elvis picture. They start talking about some book --

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What book?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Do you remember what it was about?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Shit, you know how I am about books. (more)  55. COLONEL PARKER(continuing) So I let them talk for a while, then I say, I don't care what the picture is. You let us pick the music, pay us each a million dollars, and we'll get to the set on time. About two hours later, my phone rings. They tell me they're willing to meet my price.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You don't remember the story at all?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: It was about two guys makin' a million dollars. Have you gone deaf? No one makes that kind of money in this town.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I don't want to do another cookie cutter picture.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Remember "Wild in the Country"? That film you did that was full of psychology and crap? Goodness be, that was interesting. So damn interesting that no one went to see it.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: We shouldn'ta put in the songs.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: The record was the only part that made money. People go to your pictures to hear you sing.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: People get tired of the same old thing.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: You were a millionaire thirteen months after you signed on with me. Are you trying to tell me I don't know my business?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You don't think I can cut it on acting alone.  56.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Everyone wants to be something they're not. I'd bet my last nickel that Jimmy Dean and Marlon Brando wished they could sing like you.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Anne glances up from her work. She sees Elvis sitting bef the Colonel with his head hung low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in her bathrobe, wheeling another midnight snack towards Elvis's room. She reaches the door and is about t knock when BOOM! A shot rings out. Inside the room, a Young Woman SCREAMS. Anne turns the ot way to get help. She pauses, hearing what sounds like LAUGHTER. Joe and Lamar back out of the room, drunk and fit to be t They are carrying a television with a shattered screen between them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Is anyone hurt?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: I don't think Mr. Robert Goulet is feeling too well. Joe points to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Took a slug right between the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis is in his trailer, eating a sandwich. Anne sits opposite. She holds a script and is helping him with his lines.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (reads) "If they do send you away, Tommy, you'll remember me, won't you?"  57. Elvis takes an enormous bite from his sandwich and speaks with his mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (from memory) "Baby, the moment we leave port I'm going to dive down deep, rip my heart out of my chest, and lock it up tight in Davey Jones' locker. That way you'll know it will be waiting until I get back." Anne reads the stage directions.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: "Lucy lies down, placing her head on a soft pillow. She looks up at Tommy, sad and dreamy. Tommy kisses the tip of his finger and dots her on the nose. He reaches for a seashell and puts it to her ear." Elvis mimics holding a shell beside Anne's ear.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (mouth still full) "Listen, can you hear the sound of the sea?"

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (reads) "Tommy picks up a harpoon, holds it like a microphone, and starts to sing. Song to be determined." Anne puts the script aside.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's a little hokey.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What do you expect, it's an Elvis Presley picture.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Do you have the song?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (sings) Davey Jones' locker, Davey Jones' locker, my heart's in Davey Jones' locker, waitin' to be freed --  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Memphis Mafia are sitting around a card table outside Elvis's trailer, playing four-handed poker. The Colonel approaches, chomping on his cigar. He stands over Lamar's shoulder. Elvis and Anne's LAUGHTER can be heard coming from inside.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Who's he in there with?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: The cook, Anne. She brings in his lunch.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: Every day?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Uh -- huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis is still working on his lunch while Anne reads the script silently to herself.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (looking up) This Lucy is a fool.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You saying you wouldn't wait for me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Nope. Course I couldn't keep a straight face if I saw a man singing into a harpoon, either.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: This man you play, he enlisted, right?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (in character) "My country needs me, baby."  59.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: A man's responsibility is to the ones he loves. Enlisting is just an excuse to run away. If his country needs him, it'll let him know.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Was your daddy a soldier?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: My daddy didn't need no excuse to run away.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Problem with my daddy is he's always hanging around. Anne LAUGHS, then winces slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You don't have anything for a headache, do you? Elvis reaches into the pocket of his leather jacket. He takes out a pill case made from two Sheriff's badges join by a hinge. He flips it open. Inside is a vast array of pharmaceutica He takes out a couple of blues.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Try these. Anne hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) They're all prescription.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Are any of these aspirin? Elvis hands her two aspirin. She goes to the sink and fil a glass. He picks up his script and tries to concentrate. Frustrated, he tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis and the Colonel are having breakfast at the small t in the kitchen. The Colonel reads "Variety." Anne is at t counter making a pot of coffee.  60. Elvis is working on a platter of grits, eggs, and sausage picks up a piece of toast, mops up some yolk, and stuffs in his mouth. Elvis pushes himself away from the table. He looks down a his stomach which is beginning to bulge out against his shirt. He lifts up his shirt and exposes his belly. He pokes at with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Am I getting fat? No one answers.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I used to be thin as a split minnow. Now look at me.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: I don't hear anyone complaining. Elvis is still staring at his belly.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Anne, what do you think? Anne looks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Wouldn't kill you to lay off the butter sandwiches. Elvis is hurt. He pulls his shirt down, gets up from the table, and leaves the room. The Colonel slams down his paper, furious.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He asked for my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean he wants it. I thought I made that clear when you started here. No one tells Elvis what to do.  61.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Except you, of course. Colonel Parker goes lobster red. He holds up a finger and begins to yell but the sound is drained from his voice.

dialogues.speaker: SNAPPING FINGERS ARE HEARD
dialogues.text: Alice wakes up in Varya's apartment. She looks very distressed.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: What happened? what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I think I'm about to get fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning from work, Alice keys her way into the lobby of apartment building. She goes to the bank of mailboxes and something catches her eye. Brian's mailbox, which now has a piece of masking tape affixed to it with Kevin's name, is stuffed to the gills mail. It looks like no one has touched it for days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice approaches Kevin's door with an armful of his mail. knocks. There is no answer. She knocks a second time, harder. Still no answer. Remembering she has the key, she unlocks the door and ste inside.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Looking for a place to set the mail, Alice can't resist a look around. Stealing through the apartment like a thief, she finds that the place is a mess. Dishes are scattered about. The floor is littered with clothes. An acoustic guitar is supine on the sofa. Moving into the kitchen, she finds an empty spot on the counter and sets down Kevin's mail.  62. Out of habit, she opens the fridge and has a look. It is full to the hinges. Everything is industrial sized -- tub of butter, a loaf of Wonder Bread, bananas.
