She takes out giant jar of olives, pops a few in her mouth, and closes fridge. She tiptoes her way to the bedroom and finds the door aja Peering through the gap, she sees the imprint of a body i the unmade bed. Her memory flashes on Brian, sleeping, nu She turns from the door and leaves the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice arranges an eggplant, a turnip, some apples, and so other fruits and vegetables on the window sill. Behind her, a canvas rests on an easel. She finds a penci goes to the canvas, and begins to sketch the proportions the still life. Uninspired, she looks at her work and sets her pencil dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice rides through town on her bike. She pauses at a shopping district, dismounts, and drags her bike up onto sidewalk. She walks idly from window to window, leading her bike, n appearing particularly interested in anything until she s a fabric store. Bolts of colored fabric are displayed in window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice bicycles home with a fat package from the fabric st under her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice stretches black velvet over a frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black velvet canvas is up on the easel and Alice is painting away while listening to music.  63. She takes an apple from her still life and chomps into it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice knocks on Kevin's door. She holds a painting covere in a plain brown wrapper. There is no answer. She knocks hard as she can. Still nothing. Worried, she uses her key and pokes her head inside.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kevin? She steps in and looks around. She hears something. Snori Kevin is sacked out on the couch in a very deep sleep. Alice removes one of Brian's prints from the wall and replaces it with her painting, leaving it wrapped. She pu a blanket up around Kevin and exits quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice wakes with a start. Someone is knocking on her door Frightened, she looks at her clock. It is four in the morning. She puts on her robe and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kevin. Alice unchains the lock and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I had a dream you came into my room.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I did. I didn't think you were home.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You tried to recruit me into the SS. And then your head got really big.  64.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: That part was a dream. Did you like the painting? Kevin has no idea what she's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice lifts her wrapped painting from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You don't pay much attention to your surroundings, do you?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I lead a predominantly internal life. She hands the painting to Kevin. Kevin looks at it like he's never been given anything bef He carefully tears away the paper. It is a picture of Elvis on black velvet. He is nude with body like Michaelangelo's David. He holds a large seashel over his privates.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Shellvis.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It concerns me.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: People will think I posed for this. Alice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you hungry by any chance?  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deli is dead empty. Alice and Kevin sit at a booth in the back. A TIRED WAITRESS with tired hair walks up, her arms full of plates. She drops off Kevin's order first.

dialogues.speaker: TIRED WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Short stack of blueberry pancakes, side sausage, side bacon, home fries, fruit cup, toasted bagel with cream cheese. (turns to Alice) And one coffee. Will there be anything else? Kevin looks at Alice's coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'll have a coffee too, please. The Waitress walks off. Alice looks at Kevin's food, her eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Food's the only thing I still enjoy. The Waitress brings his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thank you. Alice watches him eat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you work?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Sometimes. I'm a musician, I was in a band.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: My birthday's in a couple of weeks. I'll be twenty-four. Alice is shocked.  66.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know those guys who guess your age at carnivals? Alice nods.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I can beat them. Alice reaches for his bagel.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Of course not. She takes a bite and puts it back. Kevin looks down at th table.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know how they say that some people are born with old souls? That they must've gone through the circle of life and death many times before because they seem to have wisdom beyond their years?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you think that's you?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Because you're so wise?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Because I'm so tired.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Would you say the honeymoon is over?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: No. Thank you for the painting.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis stands on the railing of a ship in the midst of a storm. Huge waves wash over him. Pull back to reveal that he is on a set being rocked back and forth by two Stageha The water comes from buckets, the wind from large, powerf fans.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Cut! Elvis is helped off the set and is immediately toweled of the Makeup Person. Lamar meets up and walks beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Anne here yet?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Anne, the cook.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: No one told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in her room, packing her things. Outside, a car c be heard pulling up and coming to an abrupt stop. She clo the lid of her suitcase and pushes down hard, trying to m the latches catch. Elvis appears in the doorway. He is in jeans and a t-shir His hair is still wet and is a mess.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I mouthed off to the Colonel and he fired me.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: The most cantankerous things just seem to come flying out of my mouth, I don't know what is wrong with me lately.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I thought that was just the way you were.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's not. Can you apologize for me?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What did you say to him?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: He was angry because I told you you're getting fat. Heaven forbid someone should tell you the truth for once in your life. See, there I go again. Elvis looks down at his stomach. Anne nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: It's your fault.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I just make the food, I don't put it in your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You don't have to make it so good.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I also accused him of running your life.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're not afraid of anyone, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Not lately. Anne's left arm begins to quiver. She hides it behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: If I talk to the Colonel, will you stay?  69.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don't tell him I'm going to hold my tongue, because apparently I'm not capable.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Wouldn't dream of it. The quiver becomes a shake. Anne clamps onto her left han with her right, trying to still it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Now leave me be, I have to unpack. Elvis smiles and leaves the room. Anne releases her arm. tremors spread from her arm to her shoulders. Then, her whole body begins to shake. Frightened, she slips into her bathroom and locks the doo

dialogues.speaker: ANNE'S BATHROOM
dialogues.text: She sits down on the toilet, still shaking. She takes dee breaths trying to control herself, but her will does not her own. After a moment, the tremors pass. She goes to the sink an finds some aspirin. She looks at the mirror and meets eye with her reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits on a bench in an examining room, looking fright and spent. DR. NORTHROP, early sixties, kind, enters with clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: Hello, Anne, how are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Better. Fine, actually.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: (refers to chart) You say this is the first time you've had a seizure of any kind. There's no history of epilepsy in your family?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No, sir.  70.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: Have you had any headaches, nausea?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Headaches.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: Have you noticed or has anyone commented on sudden mood swings or changes in your personality?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Yes. Dr. Northrop thinks a moment. He hands his chart and a pe to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: Would you sign your name here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What am I signing?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: Nothing, it's a test of your motor skills. Anne takes the pen and signs. She finds it surprisingly difficult. The resulting signature is an uncontrolled squiggly mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red stands beside his car, holding the door for Anne. She slides inside and he closes it behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and Red ride down Wilshire Blvd. Red shakes two Tareytons out of their pack and hands one to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: So what'd the doctor say?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing really. He gave me some pills, wants me to come in for more tests. Red ignites his Zippo and passes it to Anne. She lights h cigarette and takes a deep drag.  71.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Could you not tell Elvis I was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is out on the patio in a sundress and hat. A book is open on her lap. Her eyes are closed and she has dozed of Elvis comes out of the house. He is about to say somethin when, noticing she's asleep, he pauses to look at her. He approaches cautiously, kneels down, and shakes her arm Anne opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I was sleeping. It is my day off.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Feel like keeping the boss company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne waits while Elvis kick starts his “57 Harley. The engine jumps to life on the second kick with a loping ras

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (over the sound of the motor) Hop on! Anne bunches her dress up between her legs and climbs on behind him. Elvis dumps the bike into gear and they take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis and Anne sweep down the curving, tree-lined street heading east through Beverly Hills. Anne has one arm arou Elvis's waist and is clutching her hat with the other to it from blowing away. Elvis cracks the throttle to make a pass. Anne shrieks happily.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in the control booth of a Los Angeles recording studio. An ENGINEER sits at the control board. Colonel Parker is in attendance as is the Director of the film. The Colonel does not appear pleased to be sharing space w Anne.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SOUNDPROOF GLASS
dialogues.text: Are Elvis, four BACKUP SINGERS, and his BAND. The band is the final stages of setting up. The Sound Engineer speaks into his intercom.

dialogues.speaker: SOUND ENGINEER
dialogues.text: (through speaker) Elvis? We're ready. Should we start with "Davey Jones' Locker"?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CONTROL BOOTH
dialogues.text: The Director turns to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (smiling proudly) I wrote that one myself.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STUDIO
dialogues.text: Elvis looks over the music on his bandstand. He leans ove his microphone.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: It's a little early in the morning to take on that masterpiece. I think I'd better warm up first. The Band Members and Backup Singers CHUCKLE.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Any requests?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I've got one. The Sound Engineer directs her to the microphone.  73.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (into mic) Could you play "So Glad You're Mine"?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't a fan. Anne smiles and leans back to avoid the Colonel's glare.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STUDIO
dialogues.text: Elvis turns to his Band.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You boys remember that little blast from the past?

dialogues.speaker: PIANO PLAYER
dialogues.text: I think we can manage. Elvis nods to the drummer. He counts off a free bar and t begin to play.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (sings) My baby's long and tall, she's like a cannonball, said every time she loves me, lord you can hear me squall -- I cried, ooooowee, I believe I changed my mind. I said I'm so glad I'm livin', I cried I'm so glad you're mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis pilots his bike into the parking lot of a Cadillac dealership on Wilshire Blvd. in Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis is inspecting a shiny new convertible. It is silver blue with a white interior and a white top. Anne stands b trying to get her hair back under control.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's a pretty car. Are you going to buy it? A DEALER approaches.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I already did. The Dealer hands Elvis the keys. He offers them to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I bought it for you. It takes a moment to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's a nice thought, but I won't accept.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I can't take it back.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Of course you can.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No, I can't, get in. Elvis opens the door for Anne. She gets in and slides ove to the passenger seat. Elvis sits down beside her

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CADILLAC
dialogues.text: Elvis points to a custom gold plaque set in the dash. Ann looks. The plaque has been engraved: To Anne Carver. Love, Elvis For some reason this makes her sad.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) When I was a little boy, my daddy was sent to prison for writing a bad check. My momma worked her fingers to the bone for me. She used to pick cotton in the fields and drag me behind her on a burlap sack. When I started making money, I wanted to pay her back for all she'd gone through raising me. I bought her a nice new house in Memphis as soon as I could. The neighbors got upset with her “cuz she was keeping chickens in the yard and they didn't want no livestock in their neighborhood. (more)  75. ELVIS(continuing) I never knew that chickens were livestock, but what can you say? She just didn't fit in. Then I bought Graceland and moved her and my Daddy in with me. She could do whatever she wanted at Graceland and I think for a while she was happy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Is Graceland as pretty as its name?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'd like very much to see it someday.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'll make sure you do.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Promise. So what about the car?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You can't buy people's love.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No, but you can buy them Cadillacs. Anne thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I don't have a license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne's new Cadillac is circling the drive. The car swerve wildly, its speed increasing with each loop.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CADILLAC
dialogues.text: Anne is driving, having the time of her life. Elvis sits beside her, genuinely frightened.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Brake, hit the brake.  76. Anne keeps accelerating. They veer off the driveway, head straight for the garage. Elvis reaches over with his foot and stomps on the brake.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: The massive Cadillac skids to a stop just a few feet shy the garage door.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CADILLAC
dialogues.text: Elvis breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your stopping could use a little work. He looks to Anne. Her arm is across the steering wheel an her head is leaned up against it.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Headache. It came on so suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits alone at the kitchen table over a plate of col fried chicken and cole slaw. He is drinking a Pepsi, look over the lit-up L.A. basin. Maggie approaches and reaches for his plate.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Finished? Elvis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits down at the piano. He lifts the cover and slow begins to play a spiritual.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne's door is slightly ajar. Elvis knocks softly and enters. He goes to Anne's bed and sits down beside her.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Still hurt? Anne nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Here. He gently props her head up on a pillow and massages her temples with his fingertips. Anne's face eases as some of the tension is released.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis wakes in Anne's bed. The drapes are open, allowing harsh light into the room. Elvis is shirtless. He raises the covers and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Lord, what have I done --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits at the kitchen table in her robe. The newspaper and a cup of coffee are before her. Elvis enters the room jeans and a white t-shirt. Anne smiles at him and gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Good morning. Elvis sits down, searching for the will to speak Alice finds a cup in the cupboard and fills it full of co from a pot on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thank you for last night. Anne adds cream to the coffee and a lot of sugar. She set it down before Elvis and resumes her seat. Elvis takes a deep pull.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I do believe you have a healing touch.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You don't remember?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Not past ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I was in a lot of pain. You laid beside me and helped me through it.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Give it to me straight.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: At some point in the night you must've stripped yourself out of your clothes, because when I woke up you were naked as a jaybird.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: That wasn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: There are a lot of women who would pay good money to wake up and find me in such a state.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Even more who get to for free. Elvis thinks.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Did you look?  79.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I will not dignify that with a response.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I've got to keep myself pure, I've got a little girl waiting for me back in Memphis.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: How old is she? Thirteen?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: She's seventeen and I haven't laid a finger on her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Do you love her?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Like she was my other half.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Are you going to do right by her?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'm gonna give it everything I've got.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I have another question. She takes an instamatic camera from her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Does Kodak develop X-rated photographs? Elvis snatches the camera from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red waits behind the wheel of Anne's new Cadillac, readin the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits on a lab table in a paper gown. Her head is clamped into a restraint that keeps it perfectly still. D Northrop prepares an injection. An X-ray TECHNICIAN atten  80.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NORTHROP
dialogues.text: This is an isotope which will allow us to observe circulation in the brain. It may hurt a bit. Dr. Northrop injects the solution directly into the carot artery in her neck. It hurts more than a "bit." The Technician positions an X-ray cassette changer behind head. He and the doctor retreat behind a protective scree A BUZZING sound is heard. The X-ray cassette rotates quickly, shooting off ten exposures in rapid succession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne lies in bed. Red stands beside her.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Why are they keeping you overnight?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: The tests they do on me make me sick.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Still no idea what's wrong? Anne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: My doctor's meeting with a specialist tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: I'll tell E not to worry. Anne smiles thankfully and squeezes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis, Red, some friends, and a small group of adoring YO WOMEN, have gathered in a paneled rec room. Elvis sits on the edge of the pool table, reading from the Bible. Gospe of St. Luke, Chapter 11; Verses 38 -- 41.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: "Now it came to pass as they were on their journey, that he entered a certain village; and a woman named Martha welcomed him into her house. (more)  : : 81. ELVIS(continuing) And she had a sister called Mary who also seated herself at the Lord's feet, and listened to his word. But Martha was busy about much serving. And she came up and said, "Lord, is it no concern of thine that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her therefore to help me." But the Lord answered and said to her, "Martha, Martha, thou art anxious and troubled about many things; and yet only one thing is needful. Mary has chosen the best part, and it will not be taken away from her." Elvis closes the book and turns to his disciples.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: I think Jesus is saying, "Don't let the daily grind drag you down focus on what's important."

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: That's good, baby. It ain't the work, it's the word. One of the Young Women is enraptured and is nearly fallin out of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN 2
dialogues.text: Do you think Jesus was attracted to Mary?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: It wouldn't surprise me. Don't forget, Jesus was half man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Northrop and a SPECIALIST are looking at Anne's X-ray The circulation patterns in and around her brain are highlighted in bright relief. The Specialist points to an area in the lower middle part Anne's brain that appears as a blush. He circles the area with his pen. He moves on to another Ray which shows the area from a different angle.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is dressed and is sitting on a chair. Dr. Northrop enters, holding a chart. His face is the picture of conce

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You have bad news, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is at Varya's table.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Anne is dying.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Are you surprised?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't I be surprised?

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: When were you born?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (figuring it out) She has to die so I can be born?

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Of course. It is a past life.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But Elvis loves her.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: He told her that?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Not in so many words, but it's pretty clear. He bought her a car

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: A Cadillac. Can't there be any overlap? Varya shakes her head.  83.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Convertible?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes. But her life is so much better than mine, it's not fair

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: That's a nice car.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Could I switch places? Cash in my life for hers?

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I know this life, I've lived it for almost thirty years, I'm telling you, it's not so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice exits her office and walks up to Kathie who is help a little boy with his art project

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you ever see Varya any more?

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Varya, the past-life medium. I heard you talking about her one day.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: I'm over past lives.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're over them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: I'm into colonics now.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (wishes she'd never asked) Really.  84.

dialogues.speaker: KATHIE
dialogues.text: They really teach you a lot about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rare, clear spring day. Alice and Kevin sit on the oversized bench with their feet dangling. The view extend to the ocean. There are snacks and beers between them.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How'd you find this place?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I have a lot of important friends. (pause) What would happen if Brian came back today? She thinks about it. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: He sent me an address, a place to send my rent. Do you want it?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: My shrink says that it takes half as long to get over a relationship as you were in it. I was with Brian for four years, so I guess I'll be over him in two.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What if you came across the right guy before that?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I'd probably walk right past him.  85.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I think the misery of sensitive people is caused by the fact that they are delivered into rigid environments formed by people of bad intent over which they have no control. Alice pretends to give this some thought

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I could get my nose pierced. She drinks from her beer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Were you really in a band?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Quit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It became too much about the money. Alice laughs so hard she spits out her beer. Kevin hesita then smiles along with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya opens her front door and lets Alice inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne opens the oven and slides out a standing roast of pr rib. She and tests Convinced and shuts stabs a knife into the middle of it, pulls it out, the temperature with her tongue. it needs more time, she pushes the roast back in the door.  86. She disappears into the pantry and returns with a heavy canister of flour. It takes a lot of effort for her to ca it to the counter. Setting it down, she pauses to catch h breath and wipe the sweat from her brow. She goes to the fridge and takes out a glass bowl full of eggs. Returning, she begins to get woozy, her steps are unsteady. She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath, trying to regain her balance. An intense stab of pain hits her like a lightning bolt. T eggs fall from her hands. The glass bowl shatters. Her knees give way beneath her and she collapses on the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits in the passenger seat wearing a U.S. Navy officer's dress uniform. Joe is at the wheel driving as f as he can. Red is in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Did they say what kind?

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: It's in her brain, in a place they can't operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in a hospital bed, being fed through a tube up he nose. She opens her eyes to find Elvis sitting beside her bed, still in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You've been promoted.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I saved the crew from enemy capture. Made the world a safe place for democracy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And the girl?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: She waited for me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Stupid girl.  87.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I thought you'd go to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Do you want me to arrange for you to go home? Anne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Aren't there people you should be with?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: My Mother died a few years back. I wouldn't know my father if he was standing right in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: No sisters or brothers? Anne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Then we'll take care of you at the house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a burden.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I've been honored by your company since the day we met. Elvis leans down and kisses her on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You're taking this better than I thought you would.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I've always been a crying on the inside kind of clown. Anne closes her eyes.  88.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Does it hurt much? Anne opens her eyes, nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Do they give you anything for the pain?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Morphine.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Should I call the nurse?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What time is it? Elvis looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Quarter past five.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It's okay, I get another shot soon. Could you wait until then?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Sure. Elvis takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis is in his room with Joe and Red and Jimmy and four PRETTY YOUNG girls. Half-full wine and whiskey bottles st about. Music plays on the radio. Elvis is all strung out, staring at the wall. Joe jokes w the girls, trying to keep things light. A Redhead sits beside Elvis. He turns and taps her on the shoulder

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You think I could break that coffee table?

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  89.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: With my hand, like this. Smash right through the motherfucking table.

dialogues.speaker: REDHEAD
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) You're kidding, right? Elvis rises to his feet. He swipes the bottles, ash trays and other crap off the table with one sweep of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'm gonna break this table. Elvis stands over it. Gets in position, takes deep breath to psyche himself up.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: That's pretty near four inches of mahogany.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I seen him break bigger boards --

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: It ain't gonna happen. (to Elvis) Break something else. Elvis holds up his hand, requesting silence. He squares himself, SHOUTS, and strikes the table with all his might If anything broke it was in his hand. The girls grimace. Elvis stands stock still. Red approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: (continuing) You all right? In a fit of temper, Elvis throws over the table and stomp it repeatedly with the heel of his motorcycle boot. No one knows what to do. Elvis keeps kicking the table ag and again. Realizing it's futile, he begins to calm down. He looks a the table. He looks at everyone in the room.  90.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: That is one solid piece of furniture. Elvis smiles. The others breathe sighs of relief.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think I'm going to need another drink. Red turns up the radio. Joe picks up a bottle of wine and refills the girls' glasses. Elvis goes to the bar, which is set up on a piece of glas top of a dresser. His back is to the room. He slides open a drawer. Inside is a turquoise-handled Co .45 pistol. He drops the clip to check and see that it's loaded. It is. He takes the gun from the drawer and raises it up. One of the girls notices and SCREAMS. Elvis takes aim at the chandelier. BAM BAM BAM BAM BAM BA BAM BAM BAM! One by one he shoots out the glass shaded lamps. The marksmanship is not bad for someone who's probably had enough Demerol to stun an ox.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) I knew I could break something in this room. He sits down on the bed, still holding the gun. He is laughing, everyone else is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis stands beside a slot-car race track, set up to mimi the Daytona Motor Speedway. He is wearing a karate gi wit large Yin and Yang symbol embossed on the chest. The track is realistic with grandstands filled with spectators, an astroturf infield with fake trees, and a p row with little plastic mechanics. He watches his car, a replica of a Plymouth Challenger circle the track. Anne enters dressed in a robe. She find a stool and sits down.  91.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: They released me this morning. Don't you have to be at the set?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: We finished on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What's next?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: The Colonel's got something lined up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You don't sound too excited.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Good money.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I don't know, play the piano. Did they tell you how long you have?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I've already lasted longer than they said I would. I appreciate that I can be honest with you.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Did you know I have a twin brother? Anne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) His name is Jesse. He died the day we were born. Elvis points to the Yin and Yang circle on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) As I go around this circle from good to bad, travelling through sin and temptation, Jesse is always with me. (more)  92. ELVIS(continuing) I know deep in my heart that I will see him again. That he and my mother and I will be together one day. As sure as I'm sure of that, I know that you and I will meet again, that we will be reunited at a different time and a better place. Elvis brings his car to a stop. He opens a drawer and tak out a red Mustang and a second control. He sets the Mustang in a slot beside the Challenger and h the control out to Anne.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wanna race? Anne takes the control. Elvis lines up the cars at the starting line.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Am I the Mustang?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I like Mustangs. Elvis picks up his control.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to let you win?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Naw, cuz' if you do, I can just tell myself I was being a Gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So I can kick your country butt?

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You can try.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And you won't pout?  93.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: Pretty sure of yourself, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, very.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: On three. One. Two -- Anne doesn't wait for three. She puts down her thumb and tiny car takes off.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You little cheat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne has dressed. She pulls some things out of the refrigerator, preparing to make lunch. Elvis enters in je and a t-shirt, his hair still wet from the shower.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Making lunch.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: You're white as a sheet. You should be resting.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Someone has to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is sitting at the counter. Elvis has taken her place behind it. He drops four slices of Wonder Bread into the toaster and pushes down the lever. Moving on to the stove he lights a burner and sets a skillet on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: The most common mistake in the preparation of the fried peanut butter and banana sandwich is to not toast the bread. If you fall into this trap, you end up with a mushy sandwich that's cold in the middle.  94. He opens the fridge and finds a stick of butter. He lops an obscene amount of it and drops it in the pan. In the pantry, he searches and locates peanut butter and bananas Elvis picks up the frying pan and rolls it to spread the melted butter. The toast pops up. Elvis puts it on a pape plate and shows it to Anne. He opens the peanut butter and finds a knife. He scoops s out and slathers it on the bread.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't skimp on the peanut butter either. A thick coat is applied to all four slices.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You shouldn't be able to tell where the peanut butter ends and the bananas begin. Elvis puts two of the slices of bread into the frying pan The butter bubbles around them. He peels a banana and sli it onto the bread.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You go lie down. I'll bring these to you when they're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne sits on the sofa with a blanket wrapped around her l Elvis is beside her. A plate with the finished fried pean butter and banana sandwiches is on the coffee table besid two tall glasses of milk. Anne picks up a sandwich. She looks at Elvis's expectant face and takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (swallowing hard) Good. Thank you. Elvis removes a heavy gold chain with a crucifix from his neck and places it on hers.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Please, don't give me anything else.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I'm a performer. I don't give, I don't live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in bed, the light is on low. She is taking deep breaths. Tears run down her cheeks. She is in great pain. Elvis enters the room. He moves quietly across the floor sits down on the edge of her bed. Anne grasps his hand and squeezes.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: It's okay. Everything's going to be okay -- His presence has a calming effect on her. She lets his ha fall. He reaches up and applies pressure to her temples. Her breathing gradually deepens and evens.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) There's nothing to be afraid of -- Anne drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Alice. Alice. Alice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya is on her feet, shaking Alice with all her might. S won't wake up. Giving up, Varya goes to the phone and punches a number.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: I knew this one was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Varya's brother RALPH, a stout man in paint-splattered coveralls, stands on her doorstep. Varya opens the door.  96.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Ralph, good. Come in, come in -- Varya hustles him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits at Varya's table. She is in a deep trance. The is the trace of a smile on her lips. Ralph and Varya stand before her.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (heavy accent) Did you try cold water?

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: I tried everything. She won't wake up. Ralph slaps Alice's face.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Hey, you. Wake up. Alice doesn't budge.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is very strange. Varya looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: I have another customer in five minutes! I just can't have her sitting here like this. Varya takes Alice by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't just stand there! Help me move her.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ralph carries Alice. arya opens the door to a large close and Ralph sets her inside.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with her?  97.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: I don't have time to think about that now.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: I could use her as a model. She sits very still. Varya closes the closet door, leaving Alice in complete darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne wakes to find Elvis sleeping beside her, holding her hand. She slides out of bed carefully, so as not to wake and pads across the floor to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne enters her bathroom and closes the door quietly behi her. She leans into the mirror and looks with dismay at t bags under her eyes. She holds up her hand. It is shaking. She pulls open a drawer beside the sink and reaches for a bottle of prescription pain killers. She pops the top and fishes for the pills. She winces, reacting to a terrible flash of pain. Her vision darkens the room starts to swim before her eyes. Another flash of pain, one hundred times stronger than anything she's ever felt before. Her knees fold beneath h like broken matchsticks. She collapses on the cold tile. The aspirin bottle falls, scattering pills around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis sits on a bank of chairs. He's been awake for thirt six hours and looks it. Red sits beside him. Part of Anne can be glimpsed through a rectangular window in the adjac room. A NURSE is tending to her. The Colonel approaches Elvis.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL PARKER
dialogues.text: How is she?  98. Elvis looks at him, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Sleeping. The Nurse comes out of Anne's room.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (to Elvis) You can go in if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne wakes in the stark hospital room. She is gaunt, colorless, and fragile. Elvis sits beside her, holding hi head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Hey -- Elvis looks up and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Not so good. You? Elvis shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: I don't think I can get through this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You are loved by more people than anyone on earth. Anne closes her eyes. They reopen a moment later.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't let them put me in a box, I want to be cremated.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I never saw Graceland.  99.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS
dialogues.text: It's not going anywhere. The slightest hint of a smile from Anne. She closes her eyes. Elvis begins to shake. Losing a battle to fight bac tears he leans over and kisses her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the dead of night. POUNDING is heard coming from inside the closet where Alice was deposited.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Let me out! I'm not dead! Somebody help me! More frantic POUNDING. A just-awoken Varya stumbles out of her room in her pajam She clomps down the hall and opens the closet door releas a severely disoriented Alice.

dialogues.speaker: VARYA
dialogues.text: Leave my house and don't ever come back. Alice is ruined.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She told me she was a fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Shemp lives in a swanky high-rise in Santa Monica. He looks a little sleepy and is wearing pajamas, slippers, a robe. Alice sits on his sofa, fighting back tears.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: She said I was nuts and that she wouldn't see me anymore. Dr. Shemp passes her a box of tissues. Alice takes one an dries her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How could I have made all that up?  100.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Your subconscious was trying to heal the wound created by the loss of your fiancee. Since you were not ready to face it in reality, it was cushioning the blow. With most people this process would have manifested itself in simple denial, but since you are a creative person, your subconscious devised a creative solution. Alice is now crying full force. Dr. Shemp's heart goes ou He gets up from his chair and sits beside her. He puts hi arm around her and cradles her head against his shoulder. Alice stiffens. He guides her face towards him and leans in to kiss her. Alice recoils in horror.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: I was going to kiss you. Alice goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. She jumps to her feet, picks up her purse.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: You must've known I was attracted to you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: This isn't happening. She grabs her coat and reaches for the door. Dr. Shemp go after her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: Wait, we should talk. Alice can't even look at him.  101.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHEMP
dialogues.text: (continuing) We need to process what's happened here. Ignoring him, Alice pushes through the door and SLAMS it behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice gets out of a cab and enters her building. She stil looks completely at sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice approaches Kevin's door. She finds it slightly ajar She knocks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Kevin? Alice pushes open the door and enters the apartment. She gasps. Standing in the middle of the room, amongst backpacks and duffel bags is Brian.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Alice. It's good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Brian. Where's Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I called from the airport. Told him I was coming. He was gone when I got here.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You don't know where he went?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You didn't know him from before?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No. He just answered an ad. Are you guys friends or something?  102. Alice sits, hides her face in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Are you back for good? Brian sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No. I came to pack up the rest of my stuff. We need to talk. Something happened to me in Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salmon fishing boat is anchored off a majestic coastlin

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: A group of manly, hardened DECK HANDS are hauling in a he net. Brian stands alongside them. He looks a little out o his element, but he's working hard to keep up. He looks to the Deck Hand next to him. He is muscular and deeply tanned. His hair is closely cropped. A prominent tattoo of an anchor has been needled into his bicep. Brian can't remove his eyes from him. The Deck Hand retur his look unflinchingly. An ocean of shared and unspoken knowledge opens up between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice springs from the sofa and begins to pace before Bri

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're telling me you're gay?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I must have know something was wrong, but I couldn't face it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Un-fucking believable! The four years we were together, you weren't really there at all, were you? Brian is silent.  103.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Answer me! It wasn't real, was it!

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Of course it was real. It happened.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But you weren't there! I made up our whole relationship. After you left I thought I knew what it was like to be alone, but no, I had no idea. Now I have retroactive loneliness piled up on top of everything else. Brian tries to speak, but nothing comes out. Alice looks him. The Elvis painting she gave to Kevin catches her eye She goes to it and tears it down from the wall. She turns and leaves Brian's apartment, slamming his door behind he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is in bed, tossing and turning angrily. Mr. Fabulou wanting to play, leaps up and attacks her feet. This unsettles her further. She rises from bed and goes to her closet. She drags out cat carrier. She picks up Mr. Fabulous by the scruff of t neck and stuffs him inside. He meows from behind the wire door. Alice clamps her hands over her ears and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Alice finds a bottle of Irish Whiskey above the sink. She pours some into a dirty glass, adds water from the tap, a drinks it down. She makes the same drink again and carries it into the ot room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Alice sits on the edge of her sofa. She picks up her remo and puts it down again. She looks at all four walls. Her apartment seems confiningly small. She takes a sip of her drink. The taste makes her gag. Ina fit, she throws it against the window.  104. The drinking glass breaks, the window glass holds. She watches the whiskey and water stream down the pane. Outsi someone passes. Was it Kevin? She hurries to the window. There is no one outside. In fact, there is no outside, ju black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red-eye flight. All the window shades are drawn, allowi the scattered passengers to sleep. Alice sits alone in an exit row. Mr. Fabulous is on her lap, still in his cat carrier. Alice's head rests on top of it. She is passed out. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT makes an announcement over the P.A..

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We are beginning our descent into Memphis. Please make sure your seats are upright and your Alice rouses. She sets the cat carrier on the vacant seat beside her. She reaches over and slides open the shade. S squints into the light of the coming dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still the gray light of morning. Alice rides in the back a taxi cab watching telephone poles go by. They pass the locked gates of Graceland. A tired Guard stands in the guard shack. Mercury vapor lights extinguis themselves, their sensors signalling daylight The taxi driver slows. Alice tells him to drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice walks up the steps on her way into the main branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits at a computer terminal in the Reference Department. She enters the name Carver, Anne and does a search. At the bottom of the screen appear the words: © entries found to match your search  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice stands before a CLERK at the hall of records.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I was wondering if I could check the records on anyone employed by Colonel Tom Parker in the early sixties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice returns a stack of files to the Clerk

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Did you find what you were looking for?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: No, but thank you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is asleep on a table, surrounded by piles of books Elvis. A LIBRARIAN approaches and shakes her gently.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: We're closing, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: INT MEMPHIS HOTEL
dialogues.text: Alice is in a dumpy hotel in downtown Memphis. She opens can of cat food and spreads it out on a paper plate for M Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tour bus HISSES to a stop outside of Elvis's estate. TOURISTS file out. Some snap pictures, all look to the ho wonderstruck, as if they'd just stepped through the pearl gates. Alice is amongst them. A PORTLY FELLOW, beside himself with excitement, shoots o half a roll of film and turns to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY FELLOW
dialogues.text: Is this your first time?  106.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's beginning to look that way. Portly Fellow looks at her funny. A TOUR GUIDE holds up h hand and waves.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Welcome to Graceland! The crowd quiets a bit.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Please line up beside the gates, our tour begins in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tour Guide leads the group into the music room. A bla Story and Clark piano is contrasted against white carpet shiny golden drapes.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Friends and musicians would come to this room to sing and jam. Notable amongst them was James Brown. Although Elvis was most often seen with a guitar and could play it well, his instrument of choice was the piano. The Tour has gathered in the TV ROOM: A stark contrast to the tacky elegance of the Music Room, TV Room is all mirrors and seventies low fashion. A porcelain Monkey sits on a gilded coffee table. The Tour moves through the POOL ROOM: Four hundred yards of psychedelic fabric are stapled to t ceiling in pleats which converge at the center. The effec is dizzying. The tour gazes in wonder at the JUNGLE ROOM: A waterfall trickles over the slumpstone bricks which mak the far wall. Giant hand-carved chairs stand in three corners of the room, covered in what looks like zebra ski Statuary includes rams, lions, tigers, and of course, a monkey.  107.

dialogues.speaker: THE AUTOMOBILE MUSEUM
dialogues.text: The group has scattered about. Some look at the Pink Cadillac Fleetwood, others the ~56 Eldorado painted shock purple. Alice stands before the motorcycle exhibit, paying partic attention to a °57 Harley, just like the one Elvis took A for a ride on.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Elvis probably purchased over three hundred cars in his lifetime, and gave most of them away. He was a man of enormous appetites. If he liked something he would have to have ten of them, nothing was ever done in moderation. Alice raises her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you know if Elvis ever had a cook working for him named Anne Carver? The Tour Guide thinks.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've never heard that name.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It would have been while he was in Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (to the group) If you'll please follow me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tour stands in the Meditation Garden before the grave Elvis, his Mother Gladys, and his father Vernon.  108.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Elvis died August 16, 1977 and was buried here in the Meditation Garden beside his beloved mother Gladys. Alice reaches through the fence and lays her hand on his grave.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiles) There are those, of course, who believe Elvis lives to this day. I'll let you draw your own conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice sits on a bench across the street from Graceland, waiting for the bus to take her back to the hotel. Member of her tour are milling about. One of them steps aside, clearing her line of sight to a telephone pole which various ads and fliers have been sta to. A bright yellow one catches her eye.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCES WITH THE KING
dialogues.text: Beneath the writing is a silhouette of Elvis and a teleph number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice and five other CUSTOMERS are sitting around a felt- topped table in a dark room full of red velvet and beads. the center of the table is a crystal ball, behind the cry ball is a SCARLETT, a medium. She strokes the crystal bal putting herself into a kind of trance.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: We must now all join hands. They do.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: (continuing) Close your eyes and direct all your thoughts to summoning Elvis from the great beyond.  109. The room is dead silent.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wait, I think I hear something! SHUFFLING FOOTSTEPS, followed by the sound of JINGLING go chains.

dialogues.speaker: SCARLETT
dialogues.text: (continuing) The King! He's here! Everyone opens their eyes. Behind a semi-transparent scre stands a bad ELVIS IMPERSONATOR.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIS IMPERSONATOR
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Elvis Presley. Everyone is impressed but Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Give me a break. She gets up from the table and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is at the counter, paying for a six-pack. She notic something on the shelf above the Cashier. It is a Jim Bea Elvis decanter. A white porcelain figurine of Elvis ina karate pose. The dates of his birth and death are embosse in gold leaf at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is in the bus, staring out the window, watching the lights of Memphis recede behind her. Mr. Fabulous, in his carrier, is beside her. The Elvis decanter, in a plastic bag, is on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struggling with her luggage, Alice opens the door to her apartment. She enters the living room and sets the cat carrier down on the floor. She opens the wire door and Mr Fabulous sprints out of the apartment like a cat possesse Alice goes after him.  110.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Looking around, Alice sees his puffy tail zip around the corner. She follows. She rounds the corner just in time to see him disappear i Brian's apartment. She continues her pursuit, albeit with some trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: The apartment has been completely cleaned out. There is n a stitch of furniture, a shred of clothing, or scrap of paper. All the doors and windows have been left open for airing. Alice looks around aimlessly. Mr. Fabulous comes to her rubbing himself up against her shins. She picks him up without thinking and wanders into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: The refrigerator, like the rest of the apartment, has bee cleaned out and left open. Alice stands and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice supervises a group of FIFTEEN KIDS, all about nine years old. The kids are making hats out of different scra of colored foam and fabric and are having the time of the lives. Alice notices that one of the kids, JEROME, looks very sa He is sitting apart from the others and isn't working. Al goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Jerome, where's your hat?

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: I don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You were working on one a little while ago.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: It's a dumb hat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Who said that?  111.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: Someone.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Could I see it? Reluctantly, Jerome reaches under the table and retrieves hat. He puts it on his head. It's a crazy, tall, Mad Hatt kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wow! Jerome pulls the hat from his head.

dialogues.speaker: JEROME
dialogues.text: I told you it was dumb.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's not dumb, it's fantastic. Come with me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerome stands beside Alice's desk. He is looking down at Polaroid photograph, watching the image develop. It revea itself to be a picture of him wearing the hat, smiling a broad, gap-toothed smile. Alice takes a photo album from a shelf and sets it on her desk. Jerome watches as she opens it and flips through th pages. They are filled with photographs of kids in crazy hats.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I like to save all the best work so I can have it forever and show other people. She takes Jerome's photo and places it on a blank page in album.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sometimes people say mean things because they're jealous.  112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The museum is closed. Alice has stayed late to catch up o some paperwork that is stacked high on her desk. She reac for a bundle of mail, removes the rubber band, and flips through it. Amongst the junk is something personal -- a colored envel with her name written sloppily across the surface. She op it. Inside is a handwritten invitation in the same sloppy script. It reads: Birthday Party for Kevin August 16, 2001 114 6th Street 8 p.m. Alice looks at her watch. It is quarter past seven. The date on her Simpson's desk calender indicates that it is

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up in front of a three-story brick house in Hancock Park. Alice pays the driver and hops out. She has put on a dress and a long coat. In her arms is an oblong, wrapped package. Comparing the address beside the door wi the one on her invitation, Alice hurries up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bear of a woman, who could only be KEVIN'S MOTHER, answ the door. She is somewhat formal in a billowy silk dress. She is so happy to see Alice she blushes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hi, Is this where Kevin Waterman lives?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN'S MOTHER, (HEAVY GERMAN ACCENT)
dialogues.text: Yes, darling, come in, come in. She leads Alice inside. The house is old-world European. Heavy chandeliers. Framed landscapes and worn velvet chai Classical music can be heard coming from a distant room.  113.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Let me take this. She strips Alice of her coat.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Kevin is in the study at the end of the hall. There is plenty of food, so eat, please eat. Kevin's Mother disappears with Alice's coat. Alice walks down the hallway, the music grows louder as s goes. The walls on either side are covered with the photo and awards of a piano prodigy. One shows Kevin in a black cutaway standing before an orchestra, shaking hands with the conductor. Alice arrives at the door to the study. The room has been decorated for a party, but there are no guests. Kevin is seated at the piano, playing spectacularly. Alic breath is taken away. Even more so when she sees the banquet. Every square inch of a ten foot table has been covered with fantastic looking food. A gorgeous birthday cake sits alone on a round table beside it. Alice stands and listens until Kevin finishes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Kevin. Kevin gets up and goes to her. Alice hugs him tightly and long. She releases him and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I'm expecting a late rush. Alice hands Kevin his present.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I got you this. Kevin tears away the paper revealing the Elvis decanter

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Thank you. It's gorgeous.  114. Kevin looks at it some more. He places it in a position o honor beside his cake.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Look at all this food.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Starved. Kevin hands her a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin and Alice sit side by side on the bench of a picnic table on the open-air back porch. Both have plates of foo and are eating happily. Alice pops a crab-stuffed mushroo cap into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You have to try this. She feeds one to Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: What happened when Brian came back?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I realized I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I think we were meant to be together.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: And how do you know so much at twenty- four?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I've been around. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Kevin's Mother finds a book of matches in a kitchen drawe She carries it through the dining room, into the study, a to the cake table.  115. She strikes a match and lights the candles. Written in frosting on the cake are the words: Happy 24th Birthday Kevin! August 16, 1977 -- August 16, 2001 The cake is lifted and pulled away, exposing the dates on Elvis decanter. Elvis Aaron Presley January 8, 1935 -- August 16, 1977
